intro: Thapsia laciniata, commonly known as the cut-leaved thapsia, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbrella-shaped clusters called umbels. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often found in coastal areas and open woodlands. Thapsia laciniata is known for its aromatic properties and has been used in traditional herbal medicine.
